title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000". The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote effective congressional oversight, and enhance accountability of Congress and agencies to the public. Congress recognizes the need for accurate information to ensure laws are implemented efficiently and effectively. The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "economically significant rule," and "independent evaluation" to ensure transparency and accountability in regulatory decisions. The Act defines key terms for transparency and accountability in regulatory decisions, requiring agencies to explain data strengths and weaknesses in rulemaking. SEC. 4. REPORT ON RULES. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the rule to Congress within specific timeframes, including an independent evaluation. The Comptroller General conducts an independent evaluation of economically significant rules, assessing potential benefits, costs, and alternative approaches for achieving the same goal. The Comptroller General evaluates economically significant rules, including benefits, costs, and alternative approaches. Procedures are developed for determining the priority and number of requests for review. The agency must prioritize requests for review of proposed and interim rules. They must also cooperate with the Comptroller General. This Act does not affect the authority of the General Accounting Office. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published 3 years after the effective date.
